title: Business leaders put pressure on Cameron over Heathrow
text:
Business leaders put pressure on Cameron over Heathrow 20 July 2015 Save 
More than 270 business leaders have signed a letter to Prime Minister David Cameron urging him to support the building of a third runway at Heathrow. 
Signatories to the letter include easyJet chief executive Carolyn McCall and Guild of Travel Management Companies’ chief executive Paul Wait, as well as the bosses of Liverpool John Lennon and Leeds Bradford airports. 
The open letter from Heathrow chairman Sir Nigel Rudd has been sent to Cameron following the Airport Commission’s recommendation earlier this month that Heathrow should be allowed to expand by adding a new runway. 
“The commission is clear: further delay will be increasingly costly and will be seen, nationally and internationally, as a sign that the UK is unwilling or unable to take the steps needed to maintain its position as a well-connected open trading economy in the 21 st century,” said the letter. 
“Now is the time for government decision and action. Your government must support UK businesses by implementing the Airports Commission’s recommendation and expand Heathrow.” 
Cameron has promised that the government will make a decision on airport expansion by the end of this year. There are a number of high-profile opponents of Heathrow expansion in the cabinet, including London mayor Boris Johnson. 
Heathrow’s chief executive John Holland Kaye said: “The Prime Minister showed leadership in establishing an independent Airports Commission. It unanimously concluded that expanding Heathrow is the best way of securing Britain’s future as a powerhouse in the global economy. 
“Now the Prime Minister has the opportunity to show he is serious about delivering Britain’s long-term economic plan by listening to businesses from across the UK and backing Heathrow expansion. This debate has never been about a runway – it is about the future of our country. Let’s get on with it.”
